dialogue.speaker: Nailah
dialogue.line: A blood pact? A piece of parchment forced you into this hopeless war?

dialogue.speaker: Rafiel
dialogue.line: How terrible... I'm sorry for what you've been put through, Micaiah.

dialogue.speaker: Tauroneo
dialogue.line: The uprising in the empire continues. The apostle's people await her return as they fight against the senate. Casualties mount each day... We know how urgently the apostle's army needs to reach the empire. However, if we let their army pass through Daein, the senate will surely invoke the blood pact and destroy us.

dialogue.speaker: Rafiel
dialogue.line: But why haven't you told the apostle's army all this? Surely an alliance between your army and theirs could overcome the senate!

dialogue.speaker: Tauroneo
dialogue.line: Attacking the senate is not an option for us. If it were, we would have marched against them when this all started. If we were to side with Ike, the senate would use the curse against us. The death of the senate will not stop the curse.

dialogue.speaker: Sothe
dialogue.line: No matter what happens, the end result remains the same: the obliteration of Daein.

dialogue.speaker: Rafiel
dialogue.line: What tragedy... Is there any hope for Daein at all?

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: There is... One person who holds a glimmer of hope for all of us.

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: Queen Almedha! Queen Almedha... What do you know about the blood pact? You know some thing, don’t you? I saw the look on your face... You noticed something even before Pelleas told us about the pact. If there’s something you know that we don’t, please tell us!

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Heh heh...hmph...

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: L-Lady Almedha?

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Haven’t... Haven’t you done enough already? It’s done, finished. Nothing matters anymore...There’s nothing we can do. My Pelleas... My Pelleas is...

dialogue.speaker: Kurthnaga
dialogue.line: Almedha! Get ahold of yourself!

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Kurth?

dialogue.speaker: Kurthnaga
dialogue.line: I can’t pretend that I know what you’re going through, but, for Pelleas’s sake, you must control yourself. Remember that your son made his final sacrifice in order to protect the people of Daein! Honor his memory now and help us.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: ...Sniff... You’re right, Kurth. I’ll try.

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: Oh, thank you, Lady Almedha! Now, what can you tell us about the blood pact?

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: ...In the Begnion era, year 626, a terrible plague swept through Daein, killing over a thousand people.

dialogue.speaker: Tauroneo
dialogue.line: I remember the horror of that disease. King Ashnard took the throne after the plague killed most of the royal family, including his father.The tragedy is still fresh in my mind.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: That was no disease. It was the curse of a blood pact.

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: What?!

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: It was all plotted by my husband in a bid to claim the throne of Daein. Ashnard tricked his father into signing a blood pact with a traveling wise man. Ashnard convinced the king that he was signing a contract to procure the services of the wise man, which was true, in a fashion. With the pact signed, Ashnard had the wise man invoke the curse. My husband looked on in triumph as the royal family began to wither. The power of the curse killed every royal in line for the throne. It was brilliant. With no one to block his way to the throne, Ashnard executed his master stroke. He killed his father and took the crown from his head.

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: King Ashnard killed his own father? The king of Daein?! And what about the others? A thousand people died for his insane plot!

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: There’s no point in dwelling on old wounds. Besides, the peasants didn’t matter. They had no vision. Ashnard, on the other hand... What’s important is what happened after the king’s death. Ashnard wasn’t cursed by the blood pact.

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: He wasn’t cursed? How is that possible?

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: In order to break the curse of the blood pact, two conditions must be met. The destruction of the document itself, and the death of the one bound to it. Either condition by itself is not enough. I watched it happen. Ashnard killed his father, then tore apart the pact. And before my eyes, the mark of the pact faded from the dead king’s arm.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: The destruction of the document, and the death of the one bound...

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: How could you, Almedha? How could you not tell us? You knew all along--

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Because I was terrified! I knew that once you found out the truth, you would butcher my dear son to save your doomed country! I would have done anything to save my Pelleas... That’s why I didn’t say anything... How could I? In the end, though...it wasn’t enough.

dialogue.speaker: Kurthnaga
dialogue.line: Almedha, you are stronger than this. You were always the brave one when we were young.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Huh?

dialogue.speaker: Kurthnaga
dialogue.line: I know you grieve, but grieving will not bring Pelleas back. Now is the time when you must be strong. To put Pelleas’s spirit to rest, help carry out his dying wish, and ensure the safety of his homeland.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: But he was... He was everything to me... How can I go on without him?

dialogue.speaker: Kurthnaga
dialogue.line: I am still here, dear sister. You still have family.

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: Sister? Lady Almedha is your sister?

dialogue.speaker: Kurthnaga
dialogue.line: I received your message, my sister, and have come to help. Please, Almedha, allow me to protect Daein for you and for Pelleas. Do not lose hope. You are not alone anymore and never shall be again.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Oh, Kurthnaga, thank you! I’m so sorry for everything I put you and Father through... I’m so sorry...

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: Queen Almedha! Queen Almedha... What do you know about the blood pact? You know something, don't you? I saw the look on your face... You noticed something even before Pelleas told us about the pact. If there's something you know that we don't, please tell us!

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: I... I know nothing...

dialogue.speaker: Pelleas
dialogue.line: Mother... Please tell the truth.

dialogue.speaker: Pelleas
dialogue.line: Mother, if you can't help us, then there's no hope for Daein. I guess we were right... We have no choice but to wager my life.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Pe-Pelleas! Wait! Just wait! I'm going to tell you something... But you mustn't tell the others. In the Begnion era, year 626, a terrible plague swept through Daein, killing over a thousand people.

dialogue.speaker: Pelleas
dialogue.line: Yes, including nearly the entire royal family. Those who had ruled and those destined to do so--none were spared except Ashnard, who ascended the throne in the wake of it all. I've heard that tragic story for as long as I can remember.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: That was no disease. It was the curse of a blood pact.

dialogue.speaker: Pelleas
dialogue.line: What?!

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: It was all plotted by my husband in a bid to claim the throne of Daein. Ashnard tricked his father into signing a blood pact with a traveling wise man. Ashnard convinced the king that he was signing a contract to procure the services of the wise man, which was true, in a fashion. With the pact signed, Ashnard had the wise man invoke the curse. My husband looked on in triumph as the royal family began to wither. The power of the curse killed every royal in line for the throne. It was brilliant. With no one to block his way to the throne, Ashnard executed his master stroke. He killed his father and took the crown from his head. What's important is that, after killing his father, Ashnard was not cursed himself.

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: He broke the pact's curse?

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: In order to break the curse of the blood pact, two conditions must be met. The destruction of the document itself, and the death of the one bound to it. Either condition by itself is not enough. I watched it happen. Ashnard killed his father, then tore apart the pact. And before my eyes, the mark of the pact faded from the dead king's arm.

dialogue.speaker: Pelleas
dialogue.line: The destruction of the document, and the death of the one bound...

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: How could you, Almedha? How could you not tell us? You knew all along--

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Because I was terrified! I knew that once you found out the truth, you would butcher my dear son to save your doomed country! I would rather watch all of Daein perish than lose my Pelleas...

dialogue.speaker: Pelleas
dialogue.line: Mother... Thank you. Thank you for telling us. It makes my decision much easier. I will save Daein...

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: No! I won't let you die! You are all I have left in this world, Pelleas! If you only knew how much I've sacrificed for you... I never should have said anything. I can't bear to lose you again, Pelleas... Please don't die.

dialogue.speaker: Pelleas
dialogue.line: I'm sorry, Mother. My mind is made up. This has to happen.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Then I shall die as well! I will take my own life, if necessary!

dialogue.speaker: Pelleas
dialogue.line: Mother?!

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: ...Kurth?

dialogue.speaker: Kurthnaga
dialogue.line: Stop! Please, Sister. You must calm down.

dialogue.speaker: Pelleas
dialogue.line: Sister?

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Oh, Kurth... Don't you understand? I can't feel this way any longer!

dialogue.speaker: Kurthnaga
dialogue.line: I do understand, Almedha...more than you realize. Everyone, as you've heard, there are two conditions to breaking the blood pact: the destruction of the physical document and the death of the pact-maker. However, it takes two parties to make a pact.

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: Oh...I see.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Yes! Ashnard once told me he'd considered killing the man who created his father's blood pact instead! I didn't know why until now... This means that we could kill the senator who signed the pact instead of Pelleas!

dialogue.speaker: Micaiah
dialogue.line: It's possible, but very difficult. We'll need not only to hunt down the senator, but find the document, with no idea where to start. Daein could be annihilated in the time it would take to look.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Oh, Kurth! Please, please save my Pelleas! I need your help! Help me protect Daein until we get our chance to break the blood pact! I no longer have any power of my own. You're my only hope now, little brother. Please, Kurth...

dialogue.speaker: Kurthnaga
dialogue.line: Of course, my dear sister. That is why I came when you called me. I shall protect Daein for you and for Pelleas. So please. Put your mind at ease.

dialogue.speaker: Almedha
dialogue.line: Oh, Kurth, thank you! I'm so sorry for everything I put you and Father through... I'm so sorry...

dialogue.speaker: Ena
dialogue.line: Sir Ike... I've just received a very disturbing message from Prince Kurthnaga.

dialogue.speaker: Ike
dialogue.line: Don't tell me... No luck, right?

dialogue.speaker: Ena
dialogue.line: It is far worse than that. Prince Kurthnaga has decided to fight for Daein.

dialogue.speaker: Ike
dialogue.line: What?! Why? He was supposed to stop them from fighting! And now he wants to fight us instead?! Oh, this is just perfect!

dialogue.speaker: Ena
dialogue.line: He has a good reason to side with them, but... I'm afraid I cannot tell you why.

dialogue.speaker: Ike
dialogue.line: Wonderful! So we still have to fight Daein, and they've added one of the supposedly neutral dragons of Goldoa to their army?

dialogue.speaker: Ena
dialogue.line: I'm sorry, Ike. I will try to reason with Prince Kurth again. It was the prince's wish to come here... King Dheginsea knows nothing of this visit. Be that as it may, for a prince of the dragon tribe to stand on a battlefield... It is unacceptable. I must talk him out of it.

dialogue.speaker: Ike
dialogue.line: I'm sorry, Ena. I know you're doing your best to... Wait, are you talking to him with that stone?

dialogue.speaker: Ena
dialogue.line: Yes. We dragons have the power to sense the presence of our allies. If that ally is someone we care for very much, then we can communicate telepathically. With the sending stone, we can use this telepathy across extreme distances.

dialogue.speaker: Ena
dialogue.line: I just hope he listens to me. We can't afford to fuel the flames of the Fire Emblem.

dialogue.speaker: Ike
dialogue.line: It's almost dawn. Do what you can to convince the prince to stay out of this. I would've preferred to avoid a fight, but once again Micaiah isn't giving us much of a choice.

dialogue.speaker: Ena
dialogue.line: I will do my best, Sir Ike.

intro.speaker: Daein
intro.line: The apostle's army has left the castle!

intro.speaker: Micaiah
intro.line: All right. Order all units to stand by until they encounter the enemy forces.

intro.speaker: Micaiah
intro.line: Everyone! There is still hope for Daein! We are the key to that hope! But first, we must win this battle!

intro.speaker: Micaiah
intro.line: Why are you still here? You must return to the apostle's army before the battle begins!

intro.speaker: Nailah
intro.line: That army has enough troops. I think you could use some help on your side.

intro.speaker: Rafiel
intro.line: Reyson and Leanne both fight for the people they love. I shall do the same, even if that means fighting against them. I shall fight for Daein on your behalf.

intro.speaker: Micaiah
intro.line: Thank you both. It means a lot to me. But are you sure? After all, this seems like a hopeless battle.

intro.speaker: Nailah
intro.line: It's too soon for you to give up hope. You have the dragon prince of Goldoa on your side. That counts for something.

intro.speaker: Micaiah
intro.line: Kurth is the prince of Goldoa? So, he is a laguz...

intro.speaker: Nailah
intro.line: Not just a laguz. He is a black dragon. The black dragons are the strongest of all the laguz tribes. We have a chance.

intro.speaker: Micaiah
intro.line: If Queen Almedha's brother is a black dragon...that means the queen herself must also be a laguz!

intro.speaker: Sothe
intro.line: Seems like a complicated mess to me. Just the same, he is a powerful ally.

intro.speaker: Micaiah
intro.line: You're right. If we can stand our ground, there will be hope for another day. Each day that Daein survives is another day we'll have earned for it!

intro.speaker: Skrimir
intro.line: Onward, my brothers! Hold nothing back! We must end this battle quickly!

intro.speaker: Janaff
intro.line: Whoa, that's a problem... Uh, guys? It looks like Prince Rafiel is fighting for the other side. What do we do now?

intro.speaker: Ulki
intro.line: It is his choice. We can't do anything about it.

intro.speaker: Tibarn
intro.line: Well, his choice or not, it makes things a lot more complicated for us.

intro.speaker: Reyson
intro.line: He has sided with our enemies? Has he lost his mind? My dear, stupid brother...

intro.speaker: Janaff
intro.line: Prince! What are you doing here? What about the medallion?1 Weren't you supposed to be--

intro.speaker: Reyson
intro.line: Leanne is watching over it now.

intro.speaker: Tibarn
intro.line: Either we convince Rafiel to come back to our side, or we drag his unconscious backside over here. Got that?

intro.speaker: Janaff
intro.line: Yes, Your Majesty!

intro.speaker: Ena
intro.line: Prince Kurthnaga...

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: what will you do now, Ena? Are you going over to the other side, too?

intro.speaker: Ena
intro.line: King Dheginsea has expressly forbidden us from choosing sides. The dragon tribe must not fight. I shall attempt to stop the prince.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: Do what you need to do. Just be careful out there, all right?

intro.speaker: Ena
intro.line: Yes, Sir Ike.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: Elincia, please stay back. If a chance for a peace talk arises, I want you to mediate the whole show.

intro.speaker: Elincia
intro.line: I understand. Please be safe.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: OK, everyone, get moving! Let's get this mess over with.

recruit-battle.speaker: Nailah
recruit-battle.line: Rafiel! You can’t push yourself any further. Get away from here, now! I forbid you to die before I do!

recruit-battle.speaker: Rafiel
recruit-battle.line: ... As you wish, Nailah. Everyone... Please, forgive me.

recruit-battle.speaker: Ike
recruit-battle.line: Rafiel! What are you doing? Why are you fighting for Daein?!

recruit-battle.speaker: Rafiel
recruit-battle.line: Please forgive me, Ike. I only wish to help Micaiah.

recruit-battle.speaker: Ike
recruit-battle.line: Then join back with Tibarn! If you stay here with Daein, you’re our enemy! And if you’re my enemy, then I’ll have no choice but to take you down.

recruit-battle.speaker: Rafiel
recruit-battle.line: But I just want to help Micaiah! I’m not against you! Please, put the sword down!

recruit-battle.speaker: Ike
recruit-battle.line: I don’t know how to deal with this. Rafiel, you leave me no choice. I’ll have to knock you out and drag you over to Tibarn. Maybe he’ll know how to deal with you.

battle-talk.speaker: Meg
battle-talk.line: Daddy!

battle-talk.speaker: Brom
battle-talk.line: Meg! I’m glad you’re safe and sound. How’s my baby girl?

battle-talk.speaker: Meg
battle-talk.line: I’m doin’ swell. It’s good to see you, too, Daddy.

battle-talk.speaker: Brom
battle-talk.line: Meg, can you do Daddy a favor? I don’t know what in blazes is going on, but family has gotta stick together! Why don’t you be a good little girl and mosey on over to your daddy’s side.

battle-talk.speaker: Meg
battle-talk.line: No...I can’t. I’m sorry, Daddy. Micaiah is a good person. I believe in her. I want to fight for her.

battle-talk.speaker: Brom
battle-talk.line: Well, shucks, this ain’t no good at all! I hope those higher-ups get their act together soon. But one thing’s for sure. You’re my girl. No way are we gonna fight. Not for anybody or anything!

battle-talk.speaker: Zihark
battle-talk.line: Meg, why are you still with the Daein army? They’re in the wrong, and you know it. I know it’s selfish of me to ask, but I’m pleading with you. Come with me.

battle-talk.speaker: Meg
battle-talk.line: I can’t... I’m sorry. I hope that this doesn’t get in the way of our wedding, but I can’t do that.

battle-talk.speaker: Zihark
battle-talk.line: Is it because of Micaiah?

battle-talk.speaker: Meg
battle-talk.line: Yes. Everybody knows that this whole war is a mess and that none of us should be fighting right now. But Lady Micaiah is fighting for her people, and I’m gonna stick with her until the very end.

battle-talk.speaker: Zihark
battle-talk.line: Meg, I understand how you feel.

battle-talk.speaker: Meg
battle-talk.line: But I don’t consider you my enemy! Not at all. Not ever! Please, try to understand.

battle-talk.speaker: Zihark
battle-talk.line: I’m so sorry, Meg. I should be standing alongside you, but my country has lost its mind. I didn’t want to hurt you, too.

battle-talk.speaker: Meg
battle-talk.line: Let’s hope for the fight to end soon... Then, we can be together again and get back to making wedding plans!

battle-talk.speaker: Zihark
battle-talk.line: Right...

battle-talk.speaker: Jill
battle-talk.line: Meg! I’m glad I found you! Lower your sword and listen to me!

battle-talk.speaker: Meg
battle-talk.line: No, I can’t! I’m not supposed to talk to my enemies.

battle-talk.speaker: Jill
battle-talk.line: Enemies? Am I an enemy to you, Meg?

battle-talk.speaker: Meg
battle-talk.line: Um... Not really. But this being a battlefield and all, I just thought it’d be easier for both of us if--

battle-talk.speaker: Jill
battle-talk.line: Meg, I could never attack you, no matter the circumstance.

battle-talk.speaker: Meg
battle-talk.line: I couldn’t hurt you either, Jill. It’s probably a bad thing for a soldier, but I don’t care. You’re my friend.

battle-talk.speaker: Jill
battle-talk.line: I don’t understand what’s going on... This war is so meaningless. Can’t you tell me why Daein is still fighting?

battle-talk.speaker: Meg
battle-talk.line: I’m sorry, Jill. I can’t. It’s not that I don’t want to. It’s because I want to protect you. All I can say is that I feel as helpless as a plow without an ox. I wish we could all be together like a family again.

battle-talk.speaker: Jill
battle-talk.line: Meg...

battle.speaker: Ranulf
battle.line: Ugh... All this chaos... I can barely see straight...

battle.speaker: Sanaki
battle.line: Still no word from the battle. What’s going on out there? I should go to my people. They may need me.
Hey, just where do you think you’re going? Do you think the high-and-mighty apostle should be traipsing around a battlefield, hmm?

battle.speaker: Sanaki
battle.line: Wha-- Oh, it’s just you. Hmph. How dare you sneak up on me that way!
That beauty from the Holy Guards told me to keep an eye on you. So, do me a favor and sit still, will you?

battle.speaker: Sanaki
battle.line: But I can’t see anything from here! I have to know how my people are faring down there! I...I can’t bear doing nothing! Hmm... I have an idea. You! Carry me to a place where I can observe the battle! Don’t give me that look! You’re the one who agreed to guard me, so do your duty and obey your orders! Come on, let’s get moving!
Wait a minute... Is that what passes for beorc logic these days? No wonder you’ve lost your throne. OW! Stop that!

battle.speaker: Sanaki
battle.line: Are you going to obey me, or shall I have you chased back home in a cloud of feathers?

battle.speaker: Naesala
battle.line: By the goddess, what have I gotten myself into? As you wish, Empress. My back is yours.

battle.speaker: Kurthnaga
battle.line: My body feels like it’s on fire... I can hardly breathe! So, this is what war feels like... No, please, don’t come near me... I don’t want to hurt anyone!

battle.speaker: Micaiah
battle.line: Whe...What did you say? Did somebody call for me? Who just called out my name?

battle.speaker: Sothe
battle.line: Micaiah? Micaiah, what’s wrong?

battle.speaker: Micaiah
battle.line: Wait. I’m coming! I’ll be right there!

battle.speaker: Boyd
battle.line: Ike, get over here, quick! Mist collapsed!

battle.speaker: Ike
battle.line: Mist?! Mist! What’s wrong?!

battle.speaker: Mist
battle.line: Ike... My head... It hurts so much... It’s the medallion...

battle.speaker: Ike
battle.line: What do you mean?

battle.speaker: Mist
battle.line: The medallion is calling out to me... Please, Ike... Take me to the medallion...

battle.speaker: Ike
battle.line: Mist! Talk to me! Wake up, please!

battle.speaker: Boyd
battle.line: I’ll clear you a path! Take Mist with you! Get her out of here, quick!

battle.speaker: Mist
battle.line: Boyd...

battle.speaker: Boyd
battle.line: Don’t worry. I won’t die here. You take care of yourself, all right? Hang in there, for me.

battle.speaker: Mist
battle.line: Boyd... I will. I promise.

battle.speaker: Boyd
battle.line: Look after her, all right, Ike? Make sure nothing happens to her.

battle.speaker: Ike
battle.line: I will. Thanks for this, Boyd.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: What's this light? Is it the medallion?

end.speaker: Nailah
end.line: She collapsed, too?

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: I get it now. Anyone who has the spirit of order within them is affected by this light.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Tibarn! Queen Nailah! What are you two doing here?

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: Reyson collapsed suddenly. I figured I'd take him to a safe place.

end.speaker: Nailah
end.line: Rafiel fell unconscious as well. I thought I'd let him rest with Leanne. But then I found that she had collapsed too.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: And you think the medallion did this to them? Mist?

end.speaker: Mist
end.line: The seal...on the medallion...is about to break... It can't be controlled anymore... My song won't work anymore... We're running...out of time...

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: What are you talking about?!

end.speaker: Mist
end.line: Call the apostle... She must sing the galdr of release... Hurry, before it's too late... Please, Ike... I can hear...a voice... It's inside my head... The voice is telling me...that we must not awaken the dark god through war...

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: A voice in your head? Mist, what is going--

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Hey! Mist! Wake up!

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: Ulki! Do you hear me? Bring the apostle here at once!

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Are you sure about that? Mist is saying that she should sing the galdr of release. She's saying that we should wake up the dark god!

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: The seal will break anyway. If that's the case, then we should take a chance on your sister and do what she says.

end.speaker: Nailah
end.line: I agree with the hawk king. It's too late to calm the dark god back to sleep. It would take too long.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Do you think we'll be safe if the apostle wakes up the dark god? Didn't we fight a major war to prevent that from happening a few years ago?

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: I don't know. Are we safe now? But I did always wonder why Heron Queen Lillia passed down the galdr of release. She must have left it behind for a good reason. I'm willing to bet my life on it.

end.speaker: Nailah
end.line: It's the only choice for our survival. Besides, we won't know if it'll work until we try.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: All right... Let's do it.

end.speaker: Ulki
end.line: I brought the apostle with me.

end.speaker: Janaff
end.line: ...And a little extra baggage.

end.speaker: Naesala
end.line: Reyson! Leanne!

end.speaker: Naesala
end.line: Now, now, Tibarn. I know you're angry, but we'll work it out when this is over.

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: Not a chance, Naesala. I hope you've said all your prayers and farewells. After I break every bone in your body, I'm going to rip your wings off and feed them to you before you get to die.

end.speaker: Sanaki
end.line: Hawk King Tibarn, I must ask you for your patience. This man serves under my command.

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: You think I care, child? This is a laguz matter. You should see yourself out of it very quickly.

end.speaker: Sanaki
end.line: I will explain later. Put aside your past quarrels for now. Not to repeat the king of Kilvas, but we have more pressing issues we must attend to. Oh, and Hawk King? Don't ever call me "child" again.

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: Hmph...fine. You get to live now, Naesala. Once this is done, though, you're a corpse.

end.speaker: Sanaki
end.line: So, what would you have me do? I will use all the power at my disposal to help in this.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Sing the galdr of release for us. The song that was passed down from the heron queen to my mother, then from my mother to Mist.

end.speaker: Sanaki
end.line: But if I sing that galdr before the medallion, it would awaken the dark god...

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: This is what my sister said: We must not awaken the dark god with the spirit of chaos. We must use the galdr of release instead. The seal will break if we just leave the medallion alone. Please, sing the song.

end.speaker: Sanaki
end.line: Better than releasing the dark god through war, is that it? Very well. I shall try.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: What's going on? Nothing's happening.

end.speaker: Sanaki
end.line: It's not working! But why?

end.speaker: Sanaki
end.line: A bird?
A melody alone won't work.

end.speaker: Sothe
end.line: Wait! This is right in the middle of enemy territory!

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Sothe! Why are you here?

end.speaker: Sothe
end.line: Commander Ike! And the laguz kings... Even the apostle is here? I thought you'd all be on the battlefield, commanding the army! This just got really, really bad...

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Mist and the herons collapsed because of that thing.

end.speaker: Micaiah
end.line: ...I can hear the voice. Finally, we get to meet. I have been guided by this voice for so long... I have finally found my purpose.

end.speaker: Micaiah
end.line: Galdrar consist of melody and lyrics. Without both in harmony, the songs have a mere fraction of the power.

end.speaker: Sanaki
end.line: Maiden of Daein, the only part I was taught was the melody. I do not know the lyrics.

end.speaker: Micaiah
end.line: The words. They are passed down through the ages like a bloodline. Though time may pass, their meaning is never lost. When I heard you sign the melody, the words came to me.

end.speaker: Sothe
end.line: Micaiah? I don't understand what you're going on about. There's no way you could--

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Sothe, shut up and watch.

end.speaker: Micaiah
end.line: When I heard the melody, the lyrics felt as if they poured out from deep within me. I know this song. I've known it since before I was born. I am...
Good morning to you, my goddess.
What has happened? A thousand years have not passed. Why am I awoken early?

Indeed, my goddess. You have been asleep for 780 years. During that time, the world kept its promise to you for a mere two hundred years, at best. It was as you said. Neither the laguz nor beorc could resist the urge to fight. They are too weak. Though there are 220 years left until the thousandth year, there is no longer any need to wait.
Is that so? That is your analysis? Then I shall pass down my judgment. I will save them from themselves.

end.speaker: Mist
end.line: Ugh...

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Mist! How do you feel?

end.speaker: Mist
end.line: Ike, you look so worried... What happened? Where am I, anyway? The last I remember, I was on the battlefield...

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: You don't remember?

end.speaker: Mist
end.line: I had a horrible headache, and my stomach really hurt... Then suddenly, it all went away.

end.speaker: Reyson
end.line: Unnh...!

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: Reyson?

end.speaker: Reyson
end.line: Tibarn... What is this place?

end.speaker: Naesala
end.line: Are you all right, Reyson?

end.speaker: Reyson
end.line: Naesala? Why are you here? You betrayed us again, you dastard!

end.speaker: Naesala
end.line: I had my reasons. I know you'll never forgive me, but I at least want you to hear me out. But it can wait. Tibarn and I will work out our problems first. You go ahead and sleep now, all right?

end.speaker: Reyson
end.line: Very well... I'm glad to hear that...

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: Start talking, before I tear your arms off.

end.speaker: Naesala
end.line: Whatever my reasons, you won't forgive me. I know that. But I'm asking you to put your feelings aside for now. We're both worried about the herons, right?

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: You spineless piece of trash! You used that line on me before, remember?! And look what my forgiveness did to my people! You live now because I choose for you to live, Naesala. Once this mess gets sorted, though, I'll be wearing your beak as a trophy. Get out of my sight.

end.speaker: Nailah
end.line: Rafiel and Leanne are still out cold. Will they be all right?
There's no need to worry. They're just not used to the spirit of chaos being so near. They'll wake up soon.

end.speaker: Sothe
end.line: Micaiah! What happened to the dark god? Is she awake?
I'm not Micaiah. She's sleeping right now.

end.speaker: Sothe
end.line: What?! What are you saying?! If you're not Micaiah, then where is she?!
I wonder where Ashera is? We must hurry and make our judgment. Wait...what are you doing?! No! You must consult with me first! No, don't do this!

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Mist. Are you all right?

end.speaker: Mist
end.line: Yes, I'm fine. What happened, though? What was that light?

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: I don't know... But it's very quiet outside. Too quiet. I hope everyone's OK...

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: So, can you tell what's going on out there?

end.speaker: Ulki
end.line: ...Impossible! I can't hear anything... Either that light took my hearing, or...there's nothing out there...

end.speaker: Tibarn
end.line: What do you mean?! There were thousands of troops...

end.speaker: Janaff
end.line: I'll go take a look!
It's time. Everyone, let's go outside.

end.speaker: Sothe
end.line: H-hey! Micaiah! Wait!

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: What in... What happened? They're statues...

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Hey! Anyone! Can anyone hear me? Somebody, please!

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Answer me! Is anyone here!?

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: What’s this? A bag of spirit powder?

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Yeah. You said you wanted one, right?

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: And you found one for me? Thanks, Boyd. You’re the greatest.

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Yeah, well. You always take such good care of us.

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: What’s wrong, Mist? Are you feeling sick? You look a little pale.

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: Yeah. I’ve been feeling a bit under the weather lately.

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Hey, you can’t go out and fight if you’re feeling sick! You should rest!

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: No! No way!

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Mist?

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: I’m staying with everyone! I have to! I’m not going to be left behind. Something might happen!

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: But you’re in no condition to...

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: Dad never came back! He died somewhere, and I wasn’t there to say goodbye!

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Aww, but that’s--

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: That’s why I’m not staying behind! I want to stay with my family until our last moment together. Please, Boyd. Don’t stop me.

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: All right, I won’t say anything. I won’t tell you to stay behind, either. I guess I’ll just have to be careful to protect you when we’re out in the field. Does that sound good?

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: Yes, Boyd. Thank you.

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Ah, I see...

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: Then you secure it right there, and... There, it’s finished!

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Yeah! Shinon, you’re the greatest! I’m so proud that you’re my teacher!

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: Oh, come on, Rolf. Don’t make puppy eyes at me.

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: What? But it’s true! You’re really amazing!

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: Cut it out, kid. You exaggerate too much.

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Are you going to sell this one to Aimee again? Can I come along? Please?

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: I’m not selling this one.

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: What? But... Oh, I got it. You’re going to use it yourself. Then can I fight alongside you? I want you to teach me that trick where you shoot them in the neck and then--

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: We can talk about that later. Here, this is for you. Go on, take it.

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: But this is--

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: You’ve been running around camp with that silly grin plastered on your face, but I can tell all the fighting’s wearing you down. I can’t help you get a good night’s sleep, or make you eat your vegetables, but I can see that you’re using a decent bow.

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Shinon...

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: I don’t know why we’re fighting this stinkin’ war, but I ain’t about to die like a dog. And I know you’re too young to be pushing up daisies.

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: But I...

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: What’s your problem, kid?

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: I can’t possibly pay you back for it! A great bow like this... what can I do? You taught me how to shoot a bow. How to make a bow. And that’s not all! You’ve given me so much, and yet there’s nothing I can do to pay you back for it.

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: Of all the stupid...

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Ouch!

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: Quit whining at me!

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Oww! You didn’t have to hit me with that bow!

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: Did I ever ask you to pay me back? Did I ever tell you my help had any strings attached? No! Kids should be kids and just learn from their elders!

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: But--

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: If you want to pay me back, then be better than me! Doesn’t matter if it’s at using a bow or making one. Just do it better. Then I can point at you and tell people "That’s the best student I ever had."

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Shinon...

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: I look after you because you have talent. I like watching you, kid. I like watching you shoot better every single day, you know? But if someone sticks an arrow in your eye, I ain’t gonna have any way to pass the time. So stay sharp! You hear?

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: ...Fine. Thanks, master. I’ll do my best to surpass you. I swear!

conversation.speaker: Shinon
conversation.line: "Master"? I think I like the sound of that. Keep listening to me and you’ll be all right.
